p: Jian-Ming Bai is a vice-professor of Public Management at the School of Management at Lanzhou University, and a Ph.D. student recently in the School of Mathematics and Statistics, also at Lanzhou University. His major field of interest is stochastic processes and their applications, reliability, and applied statistics.

Ze-Hui Li is a full professor of Probability and Statistics at the School of Mathematics and Statistics at Lanzhou University, and is also the director of the Institute of Mathematical Statistics & Reliability Theory, also at Lanzhou University. She has published in journals such as the Journal of Statistical Planning and Inference, Stat. & Prob. Letters, International J. of Reliability, Quality and Safety Engineering, Far east J. Theo. Stat., Chinese J. of Appl. Prob. and Stat., Acta. Math. Appl. Sinica, and Journal of Lanzhou University. Her research interests include counting processes and their applications, reliability, survival analysis, risk theory, and asymptotic theory.

Xin-Bing Kong is a graduate in the School of Mathematics and Statistics at Lanzhou University. His main interest is in applications of stochastic processes on reliability and insurance, and limit theory.

details.abstract: We review the principal progress of shock models during the last three decades. Our new model, the delta-shock model, and its latest developments are also introduced. Furthermore, for adapting shock models to a wider reliability field, we put forward a generalized framework for studying shock models, based on cluster point processes with cluster marks. In addition, we provide a noteworthy case under this framework as a concrete example in reliability with an insurance background, and give the asymptotic distribution of the risk process

context.text: Agrafiotis & Tsoukalas [3], Gut [11], and Sumita & Shanthikumar [48] deal with the distribution, moments, and asymptotic properties of the system lifetime with \$E[B]<\infty\$ for both model I, and model II.

More remarkably, using stopped random walk theory, Gut [11] analyzes a cumulative model, and applies it to the insurance risk field, while the underlying process in [48] is extended to a more general-case renewal process.

Consequently, as we see in Sections II–V, the underlying process of shock models is extended from the homogeneous Poisson case into the non- homogeneous Poisson case [2], the non-stationary pure birth case [16], and more generally, the renewal case [48] etc.; while the failure mechanism is also generalized to the run model [31], the mixed model [12], the \$\delta\$-shock model [25], and others from the classical cumulative, and extreme cases.
